Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to
the violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Facility provided a 30-day notice to have a youth removed with an Yes
expiration of 8/13/21. Youth endured psychiatric hospitalization
for a short period, and staff from the facility refused to pick youth
up from the hospital on 8/5/21 or accept youth back into the
program. This left youth without placement.
Additional Findings No

ALLEGATION:
Maple Lodge had given a 30-day notice that they would like Youth A moved from
their program and the 30-day expiration date is 8/13/2021. Youth A had to be taken
to the hospital as she was having suicidal thoughts. She was taken to Helen DeVos
in Grand Rapids. She had been in the care of Ingham County CMH and on 8/5/2021
they deemed she no longer met criteria for Psychiatric hospitalization. The hospital
had deemed that she was going to be discharged that day. Maple lodge refused to
have her back into their program and would not pick her up. This left Youth A with no
placement. This occurred after a lot of discussion that they were contracted to
provide care and would need to pick her up and for her to remain in their placement
until either another placement could be located or the date of the 30-day notice
expired.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed Complainant A by phone on 8/6/21. She reported not being the
direct person involved but the individual who called the complaint in. She also
reported being the supervisor of the caseworker monitoring the case. She provided
the name and phone number of the Program Manager who has direct knowledge of
the complaint.
I interviewed the DCWL Area Manager by phone on 8/6/21. She reported
speaking with the facility yesterday and being told that the facility was informed both
hospital staff and CMH involved did not recommend Youth A return to the facility
because it would be unsafe for her. She also reported that this is the rational that the
facility used as to why they did not feel it was appropriate the youth return to the
facility.
I interviewed Therapist 1 at the facility on 8/9/21. She reported being aware of the
complaint and being Youth A’s primary therapist at the facility. She also reported
viewing the hospital documentation and identifying that hospital staff and CMH staff
indicated a return to Maple Lodge would not be a safe place for Youth A. She
reported receiving “mixed messages” about the placement change of Youth A and
being told by a hospital Social Worker that a return to Maple Lodge would be unsafe.
She also reported setting up a meeting on Friday (day after the request for
discharge) to discuss with DHHS the best option for placement for Youth A. She
reported that DHHS removed Youth A from the hospital the day before the meeting
without notifying the facility. She reported informing the hospital that they would
need to contact the facility prior to Youth A being discharged but was never
informed.
I interviewed Complainant B by phone on 8/9/21. She reported being informed by
the hospital that Youth A was to be discharged on 8/5/21 (Thursday) and the facility
was refusing to accept Youth A back into placement. She also reported a belief that

the facility was refusing to accept Youth A back into placement because of it would
not be safe for her return. She reported never hearing that it was against medical
advice for Youth A to return but it is possible “they thought they couldn’t because of
medical advice”. She reported having an “understanding” after talking with the Social
Worker from the hospital, staff from the CMH and the facility on Thursday that Youth
A could return to the facility until another placement could be located. She reported
the facility requested a meeting on Friday, but Youth A had to be discharged from
the hospital on Thursday. She also reported a belief that she was placed in a
horrible position because the facility was refusing to accept Youth A back until after
a meeting and not having the meeting scheduled prior to the required discharge
time. She reported this caused DHHS to find placement for Youth A on Thursday, so
there was no need for a meeting with the facility.
I interviewed Administrator 1 by phone on 8/10/21. She reported being the
Program Manager at the facility and was aware of the complaint. She reported
having a meeting scheduled on Friday to discuss the options for Youth A because
she believed Youth A was still threatening to kill herself if she was returned to the
facility. She reported the purpose of the meeting was to make the placement in a
“planful way”. She also reported a meeting was held on Thursday to discuss the
situation but no one from the facility was invited. She ended the interview by
reporting again that they were trying to make a healthy decision for Youth A and
would be willing to have Youth A return after a meeting.
I interviewed Social Worker A by phone on 8/11/21. She reported “at no point did
we state that Youth A could not go to the facility at time of discharge”. She also
reported an “after hours staff may have used the term against medical advice” but
that it was never used by the staff monitoring the case. She reported a belief that the
facility “believed Youth A would be a liability”. She stated, “the facility may not be the
best place suited for Youth A, but it was the only place that had placement for her at
the time”. She ended when she reported Youth A was cleared medically and
psychological for discharge from the hospital.
I interviewed CMH Supervisor A by phone on 8/11/21. She reported being told
that the facility was refusing to readmit Youth A after Youth A was not approved for
Psychiatric Hospitalization. She also reported understanding that “after hours worker
and emergency room personnel stated there was some indication that a return to the
facility would be against medical advice”. She reported speaking to Social Worker A
on Thursday and being told that a return to the facility was not against medical
advice.
Documents Reviewed:
I reviewed email exchanges between DHHS and the facility regarding this incident.
Two DHHS emails to the facility were reviewed dated August 5, 2021, at 2:14 PM
and August 5, 2021, at 3:58 PM. These emails stated that after consultation with the

 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

Business Service Center Director, Maple Lodge remains the placement for Youth A
and offered to approve 1:1 staffing. The caseworker followed up with the hospital
social worker and Ingham County CMH staff where they clarified they are not stating
Youth A cannot return to Maple Lodge although acknowledged that on call staff may
have mentioned that Maple Lodge was not an appropriate placement.
The facility responded to the DHHS emails on August 5, 2021, at 4:26PM which
stated, “Youth A cannot come back to Maple tonight, it is not safe, and we do not
have adequate staffing to accommodate her, especially with a 1:1. We need to have
a meeting with everyone to discuss the plan before we will consider bringing her
back to Maple. We are planning to hold this meeting tomorrow at 10:30am. I will
send a team’s invite out shortly. We do not plan to pick Youth A up tonight”.
I reviewed the 30-day removal letter dated July 14, 2021. This letter outlines the issues
that Youth A was presenting to the facility and the challenges that caused the need for a
change in placement. Document outlines in the letter includes twenty-one restraints and
fourteen hospitalizations all for “suicidal” or unsafe behaviors. There is also
documentation of the increased efforts to provide appropriate care which included
“increased checks, various incentive plans and rewards for safe behavior”. Increased
therapy sessions began in May 2021 and efforts were made to avoid restraints. Overall,
they reported Youth A’s behaviors of self-harming, AWOLing and property destruction
have significantly increased to the point that they are struggling to provide safe and
appropriate care for Youth A. Part of the letter includes a statement from the Social
Worker at the hospital and states, “in this writers opinion, might be more appropriately
placed in a locked residential facility so that her access to the community could be more
strictly regulated”.
APPLICABLE RULE
RFCAN contract Unplanned discharge of a youth
2.10 3) page 31
b. The Contractor must continue services to the child for up
to 30 calendar days following written request to the primary
foster care caseworker and RPU to discharge the child from
placement. A youth must not be moved to another program
or facility without going through the RPU placement
process.
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

ANALYSIS: Evidence provided through interviews and written
documentation do support the allegations of the facility not
following through with their contract requirement to keep Youth
A in care until further placement was found. There was no
evidence found to support that a return to the facility was
against medical advice and the facility still had eight days left
until the 30-day notice was up. Although, there is evidence to
support that this placement was not appropriate for the issues
Youth A was presenting, the facility was still under obligation to
continue placement at the time Youth A was discharged from
the hospital on August 5, 2021.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that no
change be made to the license of this child caring institution
